fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (a,b)\colon R\rightarrowtail A \times A be a relation in a cartesian category. (a,b) is said to be an equivalence relation if it is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.
Let f\colon A\to B be a morphism in a cartesian category. Then its kernel pair is an equivalence relation.
The required morphisms are given by the universal property of pullbacks as follows.

An equivalence relation in a cartesian category is said to be effective if it is the kernel pair of some morphism. An effective category is a cartesian category in which every equivalence relation is effective.

fr:title.text: Every equivalence relation in a topos is effective

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Every equivalence relation in a topos is effective

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (a,b)\colon R\rightarrowtail A \times A be a relation in a cartesian category. The relation (a,b) is said to be reflexive if it contains the diagonal relation \Delta \colon A\rightarrowtail A \times A, i.e., if there is a morphism \rho \colon A\to R such that a\rho = \mathsf {id}_{A} and b\rho = \mathsf {id}_{A}.

Let (a,b)\colon R\rightarrowtail A \times A be a relation in a cartesian category. (a,b) is said to be symmetric if it contains the twisted relation (b,a)\colon R\rightarrowtail A \times A, i.e., if there is a morphism \sigma \colon R\to R such that a\sigma = b and b\sigma = a.

Let (a,b)\colon R\rightarrowtail A \times A be a relation in a cartesian category. (a,b) is said to be transitive if it contains the relation (ap,bq)\colon R \times _{A} R\rightarrowtail A \times A, where p and q are given in the following pullback.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = {R \times _{A} R}, ne = R, sw = R, se = A, nw/style = pullback, north = q, west = p, south = b, east = a, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Explicitly, (a,b) is transitive if there is a morphism \tau \colon R \times _{A} R\to R such that a\tau = ap and b\tau = bq.
